Entries.default: "Sorry, I'm really only supposed to sell to captains working for the Royal Deadfire Company." He taps a sign near the bar.
"Can I help you with something?"

"If this is about the hazatōha tournament, I've got nothing to do with that, all right? I just serve the drinks." He holds up his hands with the exhausted resignation of a man who's made his case many times.
"I'd like to order something."
[Leave.]
"Try the razor skewers. If you can handle the heat." He smirks in challenge.
"What's this about hazatōha?"
"Some of the soldiers and sailors get to making... unwise bets when they play." He rolls his eyes.
"Like I said, I keep out of it."

"None of the regulars are looking for new opponents, though, if that's what you're asking.

"All the better for you, trust me."
"You're a captain working for the Royal Deadfire Company, right? Sure you are. Even if you're not, I've heard your name enough to think you are." He winks.
He leans close. "I'm really only supposed to serve Royal Deadfire Company captains, but I'll make an exception for a fellow dwarf." He winks.
"Try the razor skewers. If you can handle the heat." He smirks in challenge.
"Why do you work for the Royal Deadfire Company?"
"They always pay on time. They're run by the ranga nui, so they should, right?" He grins.

"Listen, I know I made an exception before, but you've fallen out of favor around here. And I've got a job to keep.

"Sorry." He shrugs.
"Watch your step around the hazatōha table. I haven't gotten around to cleaning... whatever that is." He squints at a foul-smelling puddle.
"You're pretty bold to show your face here." He looks amused and a little impressed.
"I forget how quickly these sailors go through a case of candied nuts."
"Careful around the arrack. It'll glue your elbow to the bar."
"But the aumaua have a long history at sea. They make up a lot of sailors and soldiers, including most of the ones that ended up here." He nods at vaguely at the bar.
"Also, I'm from a town near Tākowa. Rauatai's full of all kinds of kith, not just aumaua."
